item.title: Custom Your Site in Moodle
item.description:
This post I will show different ways to customize your site. Specifically, I will use Participants View as a demonstration.

Hide user fields

Lets have a look inside /user/index.php. This is the file which ouput the page we want to customize.

From this, you can define which fields you want to show/hide. I recommend you to setting hidden fields in Site administration / Users / Permissions / User Policies. Then, you need to specify which users you want to hide these field by update roles. Since this page is for course participants page, you may want to unset capability moodle/course:viewhiddenuserfields. Note: for the user’s profile pages, use the capability moodle/user:viewhiddendetails instead.

Hide some components

In this section, I will give the example of how to hide user lists filter (top right corner in Boost theme).

$controlstable maintains the first row right after Participants title.

The most easiest way is remove the statement $controlstable->data[0]->cells[] = $userlistcell;. However, it would be very bad way to do it because other themes are also no longer show this component. I will show you how to make it more general and put your customization in your theme.
Firstly, I will define additional render method in user/renderer.php as follows

To make it simple for the tutorial, this function only take a $content and return itself. The idea is, I will override this render in my theme, and decide to return ‘’. Therefore, the $content will no longer appear in the view. Back to the /user/index.php, I will modify the previous code about $controlstable$ as follows:

Now, the content of $controlstable->data[0]->cells[] which shows the user lists filter, is the output of the render I have just made. If you change to body of the function user_participants_userlistfilter to return ‘’, you will see there is no user lists filter in the participant view. I will leave it return $content, by that way, other themes will work as normal.

Then, I will override the function user_participants_userlistfilter in my theme, to make sure that it return ‘’. You could read the post Override a Render to know how to do it.

This post is assumed that the readers have background in logic. DPLL (Davis-Putnam-Logemann-Loveland) is the basic algorithm for SAT solving.

Examples

The easiest way to learn an algorithm is from example. SAT problem is checking if a boolean formula is satisfiable. Because the first step of DPLL is to convert the formula into conjunctive normal form (CNF), I will use CNF form for any formula from now. Consider the following formula . is satisfiable if there exists a model such that . In this example, is satisfiable with model .

In order to satisfy , we need to assign to . With this new assumption, we obviously see that is satisfied. Finally, we have already satisfy all formulas by assignments .

Assume that in the first step, we randomly assign to . With this assumption, we obviously see that and are satisfied. In order to satisfy , we need to assign to . However, we see that with the current assumptions, is unsatisfiable. So we backjump to the previous assignment and assign to . However, the new assumptions makes is unsatisfiable. Therefore, we backjump to the assignment of . And go on,…

Abstract DPLL

Before simulating how DPLL works over the example shown above. I would like to use the abstract version of DPLL which represented in Leonardo de Moura’s slides, Summer School on Logic and Theorem Proving

Each state of the procedure is a 3-tuple consisting of partial assignment , the input clause set and a set of conflict clauses derived from . I will give an intuitive explanation of each rule:

(Decide): select an literal in which has not been assigned yet, then assign it in . It is similar to ramdomly assignment in the example.
(UnitPropagate): with the current assignment , we are looking for some formula in and such that only satisfies this formula if is assigned. It looks like in Sudoku game. You may have some assumptions over some places. The other values over other places are filled based on those assumptions.
(Conflict): The current $M$ leads to conflict state where there is exists clauses such that they are unsatisfiable.
(Resolve): Intuitively, if there is a model satisfies , this model also satisfies .
(Learn): We may imply new formulas after resolving step. Learn simply update new formulas into input set.
(Backjump): Backjump to the point where we can satisfy by new decide.
(Unsat): Obviously, if we unable to find an assignment to resolve conflict, it is unsatisfiable.

item.title: Event Observers in Moodle
item.description:
It is essential to support such thing likes event observers in any framework. In this post, I will show how to defined your observers in Moodle.

Events

In Moodle, when an action takes place, an event is created by a core API or plugin. For example, core API events are stored in /lib/classes/event. All events must be extended from abstact class base. In order to trigger an event $event, you simply executing $event->trigger(). For example, the following codes is for trigger the event of adding new blog post.

Observers

Observers are described in /lib/db/events.php in the array $observers. Each observer is defined with the following properties (as described in Moodle’s docs)

    * eventname – fully qualified event class name or "*" indicating all events, ex.: \plugintype_pluginname\event\something_happened.
    * callback - PHP callable type.
    * includefile - optional. File to be included before calling the observer. Path relative to dirroot.
    * priority - optional. Defaults to 0. Observers with higher priority are notified first.
    * internal - optional. Defaults to true. Non-internal observers are not called during database transactions, but instead after a successful commit of the transaction

In this post, I am going to define my two new observers to observe events blog_entry_created and comment_created.

Note: You need to upgrade Moodle site (increment your version.php) to apply these changes.

As in the example shown above, I need to define my observer named observe_blog_created in class core_blog_observer stored in /blog/classes/observer.php.

Properties

In order to create the instance of an event, there are some properties you need to pass. You could check it in Moodle’s documentation. Besides, you can look directly into base class in /lib/db/event/base.php

Note that you can access these fields values in your observer with parameter $event. To any information you want to pass, you should use field other (variable array). Then in your observer, you get them in $event->other.

That’s all. Goodluck :-).

item.title: Multiple Languages in Moodle Mobile 2
item.description:
Change the app strings

Language strings are located in:

www/core/lang/ folder (a different file for each language)
www/core/components/COMPONENT_NAME/lang folder
www/addons/ADDON_NAME/lang folder

In order to update translation, simply edit _lang_.json file content. The syntax is straightforward: "key": "content".

Note: Use jsonlint.com to validate that the new language file is correct.

Remember to run gulp or ionic serve in the project root folder so the build files are created.

Add new language

Besides copying new lang.json file into lang folder. You also need to update config.json file in /www folder, key "language".

item.title: Syntax Highlighter for Jekyll
item.description:
In Bitbucket or Github, it is quite easy to highligh my code using markdown syntax. But in Jekyll, it does not work in the same way. So far, I only know two ways to highligh code in Jekyll which are Pygments and Rouge. Rouge is faster and easier to install but does not support as many languages as Pygments. This post is about Pygments.

Prepare

Pygments is the Python syntax highlighter. Therefore, the first step is about installing Python.
So far, the working version of Python needed is v2.7. I have tried v3, but Jekyll did not work. So, I recommend using Python v2.7. If you are not familiar to Python, I recommend you to click the option Add python.exe to Path.

In order to install Pygments, you need to install Pip which is a tool for installing ang managing Python packages. In my case, it is installed together with Python. The only step I need to do is opening cmd and execute

python pip install Pygments.

Configure Jekyll to use Pygments

Add the following dependency to your Gemfile gem "pygments.rb". For example, my Gemfile will look like

You need to set Pygments as your syntax highlighter by adding the following option in _config.yml

highlighter: pygments

item.title: Create New Services in Moodle
item.description:
Mobile Web Services

In order to use mobile web services (similar to other kind of services), you need to enable it as follows:

     * In Settings > Site administration > Plugins > Web services > External services  
     * Check "Enable mobile web services"

You can see the API Documentation in Settings > Site administration > Plugins > Web services > API Documentation
